item.title: Creating My First Website Using R
item.description:
I came across this twitter post from @dsquintana and this encouraged me to make this personal static website.

üìùüñ• "How to make a free personal website in R"

üë§ Dan Quintana @dsquintanahttps://t.co/YfWLI0RLvj#rstats pic.twitter.com/x8uNbXaGEr

— R posts you might have missed! (@icymi_r) April 4, 2020

I have tinkered a bit using the blogdown r package authored by @xieyihui awhile back when I watched his webinar vid. I got reunited to this, and now was able to have a complete setup using R Studio, Blogdown, Github, Netlify and Namecheap.

Also, am quite happy to have successfully implemented the continuous deployment from Github configuration in Netlify after a bit of some struggle.

Here are the key steps that I took to help me bring this site up.

  1. Using R Studio, install the blogdown package install.packages('blogdown')

  2. Create a new project, select “website using blogdown” and type in gcushen/hugo-academic in the Hugo Theme field.

  3. Set-up the relevant files accordingly. Refer to this link for the specifics in setting up the files.

  4. To view the website, you can use blogdown::serve_site().

  5. Setup an account in Netlify where you can host your website.

  6. In case you are a student in an accredited university, you can apply for a free academic domain .me in Namecheap.

  7. Link your Netlify hosted website to your domain in namecheap.

  8. Create a Github account and load your blogdown project files.

  9. Setup continuous deployment setting from git repository in Netlify.

Note: I intend to update this post with the specifics on each of the steps for reference.
